161541145.review:
Ok so there is DEFINITELY a good game somewhere here, and im very excited to see it improve. But as it is right now, the balancing needs some big fixes. I'll outline a few issues ive been having that have made the game less fun

1. Biggest issue ive had, the reactor system. Please, PLEASE either make it a lot less restricting, or remove it entirely. One of the best parts of the old game was being able to make massive machines that tore through everything. now every fight is agony because I get all this new fun stuff that I cant use because of some arbitrary limit put on by the devs. It makes hunting down parts basically useless once you've reached your limit.  At the very least, let us disable it in single player worlds.

2. The resource grind is a lot. at first it wasnt too bad, it was still fun gathering resources and bringing them back. But again, due to restrictions like a tiny inventory space, you have limits to how much you can explore. this one I feel can be remedied by either taking away multi slot objects, or making it easier to increase inventory space. This one just needs a few tweaks tho

3. the amount of enemies can be a bit much at times. It wasnt too bad in the original game because weapons would auto aim. but now you can only fight one enemy at a time. and when you have 3 or 4 techs swarming you, it gets rather difficult to not get destroyed completely. I do like being able to aim, but it would be nice to have some weapons auto aim still. maybe reserve aiming for resource weapons, or set some hot key, kind of like an aim down sights thing.

4. Whats with the lack of normal blocks? all I can find are these weird connector pieces that restrict me on what I can build. It makes shaping my tech how I want more difficult, especially with the reactor system holding me back.

Now, I would love to talk about what you guys added that I love so far.

1. the graphics are fantastic! massive improvement and I have had no issues running it so far. mighty impressive, especially for an early access game. you guys definitely put some time into performance and it shows.

2. the base building now is pretty awesome. I absolutely love how it has been improved in this one.

3. having multiple worlds that are actually coherent instead of a randomly generated endless plane will be quite awesome. Super stoked to see how that turns out


Seriously guys, great job. I had a ton of fun for the first couple hours until the issues got in the way. then it became a grind. Fixing those issues and giving players more freedom will definitely improve the game a lot. once those issues are fixed and the game is fun after the first couple hours, Ill definitely come back to it and change my review. I want to see this game improve a lot. Loved the first one and im very excited to see where this one goes!
161541145.developer_response:
Hello, designer here.

Thanks for checking it out and for giving some detailed feedback, much appricated.

We've just pushed the balance update that addresses some of the issues that you raised. More info on it can be found here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

Specific responses to your points:

1. In the update (that is live right now), we've expanded the reactor capacity and efficiency points of all cabs. the early game ones have been pushed up to a combined total of 220 to 250, the later cabs are now at a total of 360 to 400 across both reactor capacity and efficiency points. these new limits allow for much more freedom in Tech builds. Beyond this most recent update, we will be reintroducing the aux reactor blocks too soon. They're attachable Tech blocks that increase your reactor capacity. They were present in the demo but reliant on constant fuel burn, we're currently reworking them to occupy a restore (one of your three auto rebuild charges) instead. We also have plans for further progression-based expansions to enable even larger Tech builds beyond that too.

2. Resource grind has been reduced in multiple ways. Resource lasers consume less power and generate less heat now, and the health of many of the resource givers (ores, rocks trees etc.) has been reduced. The common uses for resources have also been reduced too, carbon generators now burn raw carbon for 1 minute (up from 20 seconds) and many of the ammo recipes have been made cheaper and crafted faster. Once you build a fragmenter you'll also find that it yields more resources than before too. The cargo space for many of the cabs has been increased and the objective which teaches you how to build small cargo blocks (cargo expansions) has been updated to make it a clearer flow. All of that is in the current update. In the next update (likely coming next week), we're also taking further steps too (like stack size increases for all resources).

3. We've not reduced the number of enemies in this update, but we have increased the number of blocks that they drop (back up to demo levels) and also increased the amount of ammo that they drop too, making it easier to stay in the fight. In the next update (coming next week) we have adjusted their combat behaviour to be less relentless (for example they won't fire continuously without any pauses anymore and their accuracy has been adjusted to make things more fair).

4. Fair comment, our thinking was based on the idea that giving the GSO one block  (1x1x1 with 6 APs) at the start of the last game undermined interest in other hull blocks that came later (why use a 2x1x1 block when you can just use more of the old reliable one block?). Progression curves usually follow that you get weaker/more limited items early in the game and unlock better/more useful items later. But you're not alone in this feedback so we're considering options. Nothing concrete yet, but thanks for the feedback there.

Thanks for the positives in your review too and thanks for trying TTW out. I hope you like the update. Please let us know what you think once you've had a go.

Thanks,
Kris

161227273.review:
[h1]Day 1 Review (see additional headings below for updates):[/h1]

Loved the demo, couldn't wait to play full release. I'm neither impressed nor disappointed. This is largely what I expected after playing the demo and as someone who has now played the original Terratech, the Terratech Worlds Demo, and now the early access release (day-1 at the time of writing this review), I'm frankly perplexed by many of the reviews left by others so far.

Let's start by addressing some actually valid complaints: 

1) At EA launch, he game isn't MUCH bigger than the demo was. There are a few new parts here, a few new resources there, one additional biome, and a few previously permanently locked items are now unlock-able. One might have expected a bit more between the demo and now, but it really hasn't been that long since the demo, and has only been in "early access" for one day. Overall, I'd call this a minor but valid complaint at this time. Only time will tell if it will fester into a bigger problem or be quickly solved as the developers have more time to work on the game.

2) The early game grind has indeed gotten a bit silly since the demo. Perhaps this is an attempt to slow down players while new content it being worked on, but it does feel bad taking significantly longer to do anything than it did in the demo. Had I not played the demo and therefore not had that point of reference, the speed might not feel as unnaturally slow, however in that case I'd also not have the knowledge that allowed me to make efficient use of my first few hours, which brings me to my next point.

3) The progression and early base building mechanics are not well communicated. Without having discovered all this in the demo already, my first few hours would have been hopelessly lost, with basically no progress being made between trying to learn the basics and fighting the aforementioned grind. This point, especially in conjunction with the previous point, could be serious problems that turn away new players before they are able to give it a real shot, and need to be addressed asap.

4) There are still a few notable bugs left over from the demo, and there are a few new bugs and quirks introduced since. No big deal, but it would have been nice to have seen them fixed since receiving feedback during the demo.


With that out of the way, lets move on to the points that others have made that leave me scratching my head:

1) Everyone is claiming the tutorial cannot be completed. This is simply not the case. The tutorial is voluntary and can be skipped (which makes all the complaints of getting hard locked in tutorial nonsensical) but I played though it again here to see for myself what people were talking about, and had absolutely no issue completing the tutorial as expected. I'm going to have to consider this one user error or just straight up parroting misinformation. There's nothing that seemed like it would be hard for others to follow in the tutorial so I'm not even sure where someone could have gone wrong, but my only advice for new players is maybe actually read and follow the instructions, or skip the tutorial if you really just aren't interested.

2) Game performance is not worse than the demo. It seems to be just about the same. 

3) The game is not crashing more than the demo. In fact it has not crashed at all for me so far while the demo crashed every few hours. 

4) The game is not some far cry from the original Terratech. The core gameplay loop is nearly identical between the two and just about every aspect of the game is an improvement from the original. There's more raw stuff in Terratech, but with nearly a decade of updates vs this game's first day in early access, that goes without saying. The only things that are truly missing and not just altered (and IMO improved) from the original Terratech are flying crafts and the R&D DLC. Both of which were updates and were not present at launch of the original game either. 

5) The game not being worth 27 bucks is... well its entirely subjective, but also a odd take in this day of soulless 80 dollar sequels with another $20 of all but required day-1 DLC, in-game payshops, gambling mechanics, battle passes, etc. Even the original Terratech is still 25 dollars, and adding the R&D DLC bumps that up to 32. Now add another 16 bucks for skin packs if you want the basic (and totally free in Worlds, by the way) feature of painting your creations. It's totally cool if 27 bucks is too much money for you personally to drop on an early access game, but the attempt to bill this as an objectively poor value is pretty wild.

[h1]First major update (5 Days into Early Access):[/h1]

I have personally put 20 hours in to the game since EA launch now. Unlike the demo, I have not experienced a single crash yet. Today's update has allegedly improved stability for others who have been experiencing crashes however. 

Additionally, it cuts out a huge amount of the grind that I had mentioned on my day-1 review. Nearly everything that matters has been sped up, increased in yield, and/or reduced in cost as applicable. There are still a few spots where things feel off, like scrapping a piece of light ammo taking just as long as scrapping a 3 meter offroad wheel, but that's a minor late game inconvenience rather than the brick wall of early game grind that players were experiencing less than a week ago. 

Performance remains steady and has not degraded as I've built up my base, teched up my vehicle, and triggered huge numbers of enemy spawns and debris all over the ground. In fact it should be noted that not only has performance not degraded since the demo, but the install size of the game is currently significantly smaller than the demo, despite the world being bigger and there being perhaps twice as many parts available. As such, I continue being perplexed by reports of poor performance.

Lastly, the camera height has been adjusted to match the demo. This is a welcome change and should address several of the early negative review complains.

161400659.review:
Having played TerraTech since the original early access days, TerraTech Worlds feels like quite a strange, but not unwelcome departure from the original. It's flaws are numerous, and the many negative reviews it has recieved are not without good reason. Despite all this though, there is something very interesting TTworlds does that the original TT never did:

[b] Your resources are inherently more limited, therefore the way you utilize them actually matters. You can't always just build bigger, therefore you have to build smarter.  [/b]

I think what truly defined the original TT was how the building system was both super easy to use, and allowed you to do really incredible things even without needing to put a whole lot of effort in. It was a very freeform creative experience that could go just about as far the player was willing to take it. However, to its detriment, it could rarely if ever present an actually interesting challenge. With the godlike powers of infinite storage which you could access anywhere at any time, effortless and easily farmable money, and after a bit of mission farming, an infinite source of every block in the game, standard campaigns weren't all that far removed from just playing creative mode. You could make the most incredible contraption, but it'd almost inevitably end up just curbstomping the AI without any need for much thought. 

TerraTech Worlds is an entirely different experience. Your storage is only handled locally through your base structures and cargo blocks. Your tech has a power limit on how many parts it can support at once. Most of your weapons require ammunition. Thrusters require jet fuel. The world is no longer an infinite randomly generated flat plane, but a handcrafted globe with a more deliberate chain of progression.  Heat, cold, and other environmental effects can influence your tech as you progress through the games biomes. You are no longer a god, but a mere mortal in a much smaller universe. 

Now, this more limiting direction removes the core strength that the original TT had of a super freeform creative experience, and trades it for a much more grounded and slower paced problem solving experience. As previously mentioned, it has its fair share of faults, but it also makes a concentrated effort into removing a lot of the originals weaknesses. While the two games are visually reminiscent of one another, in a sense, TTworlds shares very little game design ethos with its predecessor. It's not TerraTech 2, nor is it really trying to be.

What I think TTworlds does really well is urging the player to keep building new techs/bases, or tweaking their existing techs based on what they're doing next. Starting out I built a jack-of-all-trades tech, but found myself switching over to building more specialized vehicles as time went on. Ammo felt a little scarce/slow to produce at first, but once I had a production chain from a silo going, I had more than enough to keep me going. As I started branching out and building multiple bases, the distances started becoming long enough that I felt it was reasonable to start producing jet fuel for thrusters. I felt compelled to build combat focused techs, harvester-focused techs, and cargo-focused techs not merely just for fun, but because it was genuinely impactful to dedicate my entire tech towards a role, whether that'd be for efficiently carving my way through enemy techs and hostile flora as I traveled to new places, collecting higher tier resource chunks in later biomes for processing at a forward base, or moving large amounts of resources/parts between bases. The way the game is set up made me feel as though I could only thrive if I worked for it, which I found rather satisfying in the end.

Now, to some, this might all sound like tedium, and that'd be an entirely fair stance to take. It's clearly going in a different direction than the original, revolving around limiting the players resources, and that's not going to be everyone's cup of tea. Inventory management is also quite cumbersome, and base automation is very lacking in features as well. On top of that, the way you unlock part blueprints is tied to an unfinished money system, so the only way you can unlock all the parts for crafting is through replaying the game and doing the same missions over and over. Case in point, the Early Access title isn't just for show.

In the end, I think TerraTech Worlds is built on a really solid idea, but just hasn't quite stuck the landing just yet. It's just a bit too rough around the edges, a bit too grindy for the amount of content, and a bit too cumbersome for its own good, but the core design idea is great, and I've definitely had enough fun to at least recommend it as an interesting experience. Rarely do creative vehicle building games set out to challenge the player into constantly improving their craft, and TTworlds managed to do that to me in spite of all its flaws. I wouldn't recommend it in its current state as something to play long term (hopefully updates will come to change that), but I can recommend it as a fun little fresh take on the genre.

162657424.review:
I really feel that this game has loads of potential but i think that the devs misunderstood the reason many of us gamers loved TerraTech. Coming from the simple fun of destruction that TerraTech embodied, where the size limit on your tech was the physics engine crashing, to the tedious grind and "reactor limit" of TerraTech Worlds. I feel that a huge part of the fun I had with the OG TerraTech was just blasting enemies, making boatloads of money and building giant death machines that satisfied my inner desire to conquer the world. If the devs could get one message, it would be that this game should keep the new complexity but also:
1. Bring back the 6 attachment point one-blocks (I don't want to do calculus just to attach a laser to my tech)
2. For the love of God, please let us disable the reactor load limit in the settings during world creation or make it a lot less restrictive.
TerraTech is one of my all-time favorite games and I'd hate for it's legacy to go to waste because it complicated the simple fun of blowing things up. For now, not worth the 30$, but I expect a No Man's Sky esque comeback with this game (in a much shorter timespan because I trust the devs).

161324270.review:
Let them cook. Seems like a lot of good ideas that aren't fully compatible with each other.
Base building is defs an upgrade, but the automation aspects are a complete downgrade to how it was in TerraTech.
Visually it is a step up from TerraTech.
The aspect of specializing with parts and cabs is cool.
Resources do not seem to respawn, so you will be scrapping A LOT of parts, and then the resources from parts.
Base power system is... weird. You do not produce power per say, but rather, you have a power capacity. I'm still not sure what base batteries do exactly, or how they work. Machines take power capacity from generators. Generators will always consume carbon as power.
Automating using 'conduits' is a horrible process. One input One output. No filtering. No splitting. Inferior to conveyors.
Getting to any sort of non-burnable power generation seems to be VERY far down the progression line.

As a whole, in my opinion, seems like a complete downgrade from TerraTech (Specifically, in mechanics) . I really hoped a lot of lessons learned on what was good in that game, were transferred to Worlds, but seems like they decided to ignore those aspects and start from scratch.

I would say to give them some time and pick it up later down the line. For now , I cannot recommend.

Addendum: Playing some more of the game, more issues crop up that I will add below:

- Base building has a few cool ideas, but there is a HUGE downside to it, and it's not automation. Mobility. The base is static, where you build it the first time is where it will stay.
You can build multiple bases, but you have to build it part by part, you cannot blueprint one, nor can you move the original base without a full deconstruct... part by part (Or stacking everything to a single block touching ground, and removing that block).

- Combat. Combat . Is. Horrible. It does not feel satisfactory at all. Techs have near infinite ammo and battery pools, and near infinite range on weapons. Your weapons do not. They have a limited ammo capacity, your battery is slow to recharge (no battery boosters or generators on tech of any sort). Lasers do not always shoot where you want them to. Projectiles have insane spread to them, and seem inneffective.

- Difficulty and Exploration: For a game focused on exploration, you are significantly limited how far you can explore because of how the game is at it's base. Your tech has a capacity things on it. The combat issues really come into a perspective when you try to find some rarer resources, only to be swarmed by tech in an area.

- Progression. This goes back into exploration. Resources for upgrading yourself can only be found deep into exploration. You cannot infinitely scrap enemy tech parts to upgrade yourself due to cab limitations, and the sheer fact, that you cannot get upgrade/rare resources by scrapping tech parts of enemies. Defeating a 'difficult' opponent, who has infinite battery, ammo, and range, is not rewarding. It just leaves behind common parts worth starter resources.

-Design direction. And this is the BIG ONE. The devs decided to put experimenting with power limits and block gimmicks, above creativity. Blocks are shaped in a variety of forms, but a lot of those forms are very limiting. Everything seems to go along the lines of "If I us X block, I HAVE to use Y block, which means I have to us Z, etc". It's not a choice, you have to... like a very limiting class system. Blocks dictate design, not creativity of design.

PS: If people didn't want this to be compared to Terra Tech, shouldn't have called it TerraTech:Worlds. A certain degree of "We learned from previous game" should apply. This is not it. This would've been better off as it's own game, with it's own set of assets.
161324270.developer_response:
Hi, designer here, again.

Update: Just to say the balance update that I mentioned before is now live. more info here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

Thanks for taking the time to give this feedback and then updating it with more too. There's lots of detail, I appreciate the time you spent sharing your thoughts.

We've completed a balance pass today. It addresses some of your points of concern (power consumption and Tech reactor limits). 

On some of your other points - We'll be adding splitters and mergers for base automation soon (they were in the demo but had to be removed for the launch because of some issues) and filters will be coming after that (neither of those will make the balance update, but will follow after)

On base power we are updating to only consume power whilst machines are in use, this is a common bit of feedback and we're listening. I felt like it would be simpler to just keep it as a headline power requirement number, but players understandably find it annoying having to turn things on and off to free up power, (again, not in the balance update, but coming after).

Structure snapshots (saving and loading) and building with blueprints (we call this architect mode) will be included along with a load of other base building improvements in the summer update. See our public roadmap here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4031353167275151705

In the balance update, we pushed today:

- We have reduced the power consumption of resource lasers. The issue that you describe where your lasers are not aiming where you are pointing may be because of nearby blocks built around the laser which are limiting their turning arcs, if you give them a bit more space they may regain their full arcs.

- The reactor limits on many of our cabs have also been increased (in the coming balance update) to give you more room to build.

Thanks for your feedback on unlimited ammo/power issues for enemies, that's a fair comment. We'll impose some firing pauses in their combat behaviours. We can't give them hard ammo limits or else they would eventually sit there doing nothing, which feels broken, but I take your point.

I appreciate that you're not keen on the building limitations, the goal is to avoid the uncapped unravelling that happens at the end of the last game. Without limitations, you don't have to make any choices about which blocks to add and good choices are what make building well an accomplishment (IMO). But yes, you're not alone in feeling frustrated about that. We will add more options for unlimited creativity down the line.

Again, thanks for your feedback, I hope you give things a go after the update and keep sharing your thoughts.

Cheers,
Kris

161773548.review:
I am a hardcore TerraTech fan (over 2,000 hours on TerraTech, moved accounts so its smaller on this account) but that just makes this review a bigger "don't buy this game".
Though real quick, if you are a hardcore builder who likes a challenging build system (that's rewarding), then go ahead and pick up this game. Its a great redo of the original TerraTech and even in such an early access its quite dynamic and excels what the original rendition touched upon and has a bright future, though honestly the price is quite steep.

(For casual builders, aka 90+% of players)
Short answer: If you like building with lots of freedom, like in TerraTech, do not play this game. Yet.

Long answer:
In its current state, do not buy the game. The world is out to kill you at every opportunity, you have to grind A LOT to get anything done (ESPECIALLY EARLY GAME!), the temperature mechanic is boggus, the building system (the attachment layouts of tech blocks) is honestly unacceptable, the modifier system is rather obscure and detrimental (suspect to be why blocks are SO HARD TO WORK WITH), and the final area of the game, the arctic, is unreasonable as you go from 190*C to -100*C regularly unless you play and build very specifically and have the block you need FROM the arctic in order to SURVIVE in the arctic PLUS the fuel you need to run said block.

My biggest issue with this game is the modifier system as that clearly has played into why every tech block I try to use is a nightmare to work with.
[list]
[*]I go to make a late game tech with a big turret only to find out the turret piece I want to use has a SINGLE connection point on its top and bottom yet is a 2x2 block. Guess I can't use that.
[*]I try to use axles to make wheels not ruin my reactor load only to find ALL axles only have effective attachments on their side (only one side too). Guess I can't use that. ...but I have to.
[*]I try to use the attachments on wheels to work around axles only having side attachments, only to find out the wheel I WANT to use, decided to have a smooth surface rather than a connection point for no good reason other than to be harder to work with. Guess I can't use that!.. but I again have to.
[/list]
In summary, the building system in unacceptable with how much the game screws with you on how blocks are aloud to connect on your tech. I believe its all because its an anti-cheese contingency for the modifier system. Oh also, the build system IN GENERAL is a pain to work with. The game loves trying to place blocks where you don't want them. Side note, the tech size limit is TINY!! IT'S COMICALLY SMALL!!

During my 43+ hours, it always felt like the game was TRYING to screw with me. Either with horrible block connections, grind, or with funny plant that launches you 50 meters. Or maybe just an infestation of 10 plants that shoot lasers that make bullets look like nerf darts.
Not only is the world a chore to tolerate, you also have no proper freedom in how you build in this game. If you are in any way a casual builder, avoid this game. I am still playing it as I am not a casual builder and enjoy these challenges. Except the attachment problems.
161773548.developer_response:
Hey Nexious, lead designer here.

Thanks for checking it out and for playing TT1 too, I was the lead designer on that as well.

Thanks for the detailed feedback. As you know from TT1 we're always keen to hear what you think and are updating the game all the time. We've got another update which should be going out end of day today (by around 6 pm UK time). This update should address one of your points, about the Tech build limits. I've reduced all reactor costs of all blocks by either 20% to 30% or one point, whichever is greater.

As you'd expect, we'll be adding more blocks as we go. The reason we didn't give the GSOP one block with 6 APs at the start (like in TT1) is that it's one of the most powerful/versatile blocks in the game. Progression curves usually follow that you get better items as you go along, but we found that in TT1 players would usually ignore any other hull blocks that they found, because why not just use more one blocks? But perhaps we have gone too far with the limited APs in tricky orientations, we'll have to consider adding more APs or additional blocks at the start that are a bit easier to build with. Again thanks for the feedback, please keep letting us know how you're getting on.

Many thanks,
Kris

161627765.review:
At the moment (3/27/2024) I wouldn't recommend this game. If you own Terra Tech (TT), enjoy that for a bit longer. If you don't own any of these two games, either buy TT or give this one some more time. 

My Feedback 
(I am aware that this is early access and will update this review as time passes. Hence the date above):
- The biggest issue has to be with creating the techs (vehicles) themselves. I assume that one of the pillars of this game is to build fun, creative techs and then going out to test them. That's very lack luster in this game. Even with the chassis the game gives you for completing missions I can not evolve my tech as freely as I do in TT. I've killed dozens of enemies and my tech has barely changed, because of how specific the parts that drop are. Blocks fit in VERY specific ways. resulting in gathering pieces to not meet the situations to use them. After hours of playing my tech looks SLIGHTLY different from when i started. Compared to TT, this experience has been disappointing. 
- The UI is a bit turn off. Starting with the way the name of items slowly blend into each other when selecting selecting through items or structures. That needs to stop. A step back is needed to evaluate functionality over aesthetics. 
- The base building revamp and limited storage for parts and resources anchors you to your base. Venturing too far out just to play Tetris with your inventory when you finally find some good parts and leave some behind is a bummer (Think Diablo style inventory). The exploration aspect of this game compared to TT is not even close because of that. Having to constantly go back to base to empty inventory and building silos to store resources and blocks (the tons of blocks that don't fit each other and can't make a decent tech) is not fun to me.
- It's not optimized. I started with everything on Ultra and my PC fans were going nuts. Had to bring the graphics down and cap the FPS to 30. The game looked nice while it lasted, though.
- The intro video was gorgeous and brought context to why we are there.

If the devs behind this game are the same as the guys who made TT, Given enough time, I can see this game reaching the heights of TT. It's the only reason i did not refund the game. As of right now, Terra Tech World just makes me want to play Terra Tech. The game has a strong foundation in place. It has a lot of potential. We'll see where they take it from here.

162571830.review:
TerraTech Worlds is a crafting/open-world exploration game which combines a few unique takes on the genre with a cumbersome user-interface and many missing quality-of-life features which you can find in similar titles.

At present, the game is very barebones. Many aspects of progression are tied to building a base, but doing so ties you to a variety of mundane, repetitive chores just to keep the lights on. For example, your generators have a limited amount of output so they can only support so many active buildings at a time. If one too many of your structures are active at once, the power is tripped, forcing you to find and turn off devices until you can reset power. Buildings use power even when they're idle, so to avoid the busy work of literally turning things off and on to get work done you're encouraged to build power supplies. The first power supply you have access to requires Carbon to function and must be refilled regularly. A starting base will require 3-4 power supplies to keep all buildings active and that means you're either constantly refilling generators with carbon, or turning everything off but the one or two buildings you actually want to use at one time. This is just one example of the frustrating design decisions here.

Furthermore, apparently TerraTech Worlds uses Epic Online Services - something I didn't know until EOS went down, literally preventing me from loading a saved, singleplayer game. It also doesn't work at all if you block Epic's data-harvesting endpoints. It also means you have to be online to play your singleplayer "offline" save. So that's great.

I'd refund this if I could. My advice to prospective customers is to give this time. If you're willing to put up with Epic's nonsense and give the developers time to cook, there's a great game here. Potentially. Otherwise, I'd suggest you steer clear.

There are a lot of cool ideas here but they need quite a bit of fleshing out. Check back on this one in 6 months to a year, if it survives that long.

161339529.review:
This is an early release title, not the full game. I saw a negative review stating this is an incomplete game/full release and it isn't. I wish Steam would prevent people from leaving reviews who have a deep misunderstanding of how EA titles are rolled out. I don't mind seeing the negative reviews, but the ignorant reviews are mind-boggling.
That being said, I like the game. I'm easy to please, however. I've only got about 10-20 hours of gameplay into the original TT that I bought last week so I'm not "set in my ways". This game was sort of like coming out of a lava tube and having ice water thrown in your face as the building/constraints/etc. are completely different from the original. This is a bit annoying as others have pointed out since your tech is extremely limited.I think I'm almost tapped on Nibiru and I have yet to see a reactor expansion (not saying it isn't there, I just haven't seen it yet).

Constructive criticism:
1. Loosen up the spawn clusters. In some instances you'll be up against a 7-block scout and a fully beefed out Centurion will sneak up on you and donkey punch you.
2. BBs. Need a viable way to continuously get these early (25 per quest doesn't help much). Or just have the tech unlock when you kill the right mob and remove BBs altogether.
3. Axles and Frames - Make these make sense. If you're going to put a reactor limit on me, at least make it where I can hook the axles directly on to the frame instead of having to put 3 connectors on just to hook it in. Not sure if this was an oversight or just some drunken programmer wanting to make things asymmetrical, but my OCD can only take so much of this.
4. Make optimization a priority. Things quickly turn into a slide show around the arctic/swamp. I've had to edit my config file to tone things down a bit. I have to do this with all EA Unreal Engine games until they're optimized so this isn't a hit, I just know someone is going to complain about it.
5. Put in a fast travel system from base to base. Having to roll through giant clusters of annoying mobs taking constant pot shots at you to get from one base to another only to get caught on a jagged hematite node and I get smoked because I can't lift my chassis otherwise my tech starts melting is a bit much. The world appears to be around 20x20km and it feels like I'm being hazed every time I have to go get more Niobium. - Not a deal-breaker for me, just a wishlist item :)
6. I don't know who calculated your land mass, but Nibiru is either 3/5 or 4/5 water. 69% land mass, unless you're counting the gigantic f off mountains, is hilarious. I crossed the ocean from west to east and I can honestly say, water covers more than 31% of the planet. Way more.
7. World map. The mini map is cute, but I'd like to be able to drop waypoints on a world map.
8. Stationary fragmenters - Who thought this up? Let me put this thing on a flat bed instead of having to tear my base down and relocate it every time I strip mine an area. Alternatively, get rid of seams and make mining a minigame like Star Citizen where you keep an even heat on the rocks or you lose your yield.
8. If the answer to all of the above is "Just play with friends and it'll be easier", I'd like to introduce you to my anti-social self. I have all the friends I want and none of them play multiplayer games aside from my son. If I wanted to play a game with other people, I'd pick up FFXIV again.

I have more thoughts, but I've been playing this fairly nonstop since release and I need sleep. Cheerios!

And yes, I recommend this title despite it being early access and having a few quirks and annoying systems in place :D That's what feedback is for.

[b]IMPORTANT: YOU CAN "SCRAP" FOR MATERIALS BY DESTROYING THE BLOCKS WITH ANY OF YOUR WEAPONS[/b]. 

It reduces the terrible grind and the lack of ore veins that this game currently has. 

Review - Well, with the dramatic entrance out of the way, I don't think it's worth it and there are many improvable features. Aside from the grind, the most offputting moment in this game is the abnormal amount of open canvas that feels like there should have been more brushstrokes: an ore vein, more trees, or a baby in a trash can. This was not the case in the demo with more trees and veins, and in addition, the demo accidentally alleviated this by having a ton of enemies that resulted in a bucket of chaos. But now that we are in release, something went wrong, and the world feels empty.

So why did I leave a positive review for this game? For me, it's novelty. I love Terratech and its style of basebuilding mixed in with survival, and now there are constraints, so I want to support this project. You should not take this gamble; I do not recommend this game in its current state. But despite all those years, the developers are still updating Terratech, so perhaps they wanted to make a good game that makes me want to see more.

TLDR; If you like Gregtech New Horizons modpack from the hit game Minecraft, you will like this.

161448392.developer_response:
Hello, designer here.

Thanks for your feedback and for trying the game out. 

We've just pushed the balance update that expands the reactor limits for all cabs to allow for more freedom in your Tech builds. More info on it can be found here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

In the update (that is live right now), we've expanded the reactor capacity and efficiency points of all cabs. the early game ones have been pushed up to a combined total of 220 to 250, the later cabs are now at a total of 360 to 400 across both reactor capacity and efficiency points. these new limits allow for much more freedom in Tech builds. Beyond this most recent update, we will be reintroducing the aux reactor blocks too soon. They're attachable Tech blocks that increase your reactor capacity. They were present in the demo but reliant on constant fuel burn, we're currently reworking them to occupy a restore (one of your three auto rebuild charges) instead. We also have plans for further progression-based expansions to enable even larger Tech builds beyond that too.

Fair comment about the block set, our thinking was based on the idea that giving the GSO one block  (1x1x1 with 6 APs) at the start of the last game undermined interest in other hull blocks that came later, why use a 2x1x1 block when you can just use more of the old reliable one block? it's the most useful/versatile building block you can get and we give it right at the start. Progression curves usually follow that you get weaker/more limited items early in the game and unlock better/more useful items later. But you're not alone in this feedback so we're considering options. Nothing concrete yet, but thanks for the feedback there.

I hope you'll give the update a try and let us know what you think. We're always listening to what players are saying and we've got lots more updates to come.

Thanks,
Kris

161966860.developer_response:
Hey, thanks for taking the time to play TTW and leave us a review!

In regards to conduits, we're aware of some camera issues (updates for this are coming at some point, sorry it's currently a bit fiddly to use), conduits/automation will also get a significant update much sooner.

Thank you for pointing out the tech cargo issues, this is most likely a bug that we have flagged with our QA team. 

Apologies that you found the chlorine changes frustrating, lightning rods are your best bet for mitigating against lightning trees so you can gather the chlorine around them. Halite was always supposed to be prevalent around trees as opposed to the beach, it was added before we added the lightning trees, so we've had to make some changes as we continue to update/change the game. As TTW is a Survivalcraft game, we're following the philosophy of hazards stopping you from getting certain resources too readily, eg. for swamps you get corrosion damage, in the arctic you need to mitigate against cold damage; this is explained in the description on the objective but we’re aware the objectives panel is too hidden and these objectives need further steps to make them smoother/easier to understand going forward.

Thank you again for playing and taking the time to leave a review.

161270724.review:
Honestly, I don't understand why there are any bad reviews.
But I do like how the heat system works when your vehicle overheats.
I'm pretty sure it's effective, but remember, this game is still in early access.
I've played the original TerraTech, and it's good that there are more bots and auto fire in this version.
I'm looking forward to exploring different terrains, though the UI is somewhat similar.
One cool feature is being able to destroy enemies and take over their bases to collect resources.
Overall, it feels like the game is improving, but there are a few bugs. Still, it's not bad at all.


[h1]My thoughts on a scale of 1 to 10:[/h1]


Combat: 8.5


I think it's okay that lasers require batteries, but if you run out of battery, it will be recharged in a few minutes. However, it can take about 10 to 20 minutes to collect resources. Sometimes, it can take about 1-3 hours, which feels like a waste of time.


Some guns require ammo; mostly, enemies drop ammo. I think it's okay, but sometimes it can be harder, I guess.


Missions: 4.6


Not bad. I thought I was skipped from that demo because I can't remember it, but this mission seems to have no failures or issues. Sometimes it's just boring for no reason, likely because expert players have already completed it before. Additionally, there is no loot drop upon finishing this mission, unlike in the original TerraTech. It feels somewhat limited, and I'm not sure why a license payment is required, especially if it was deemed too expensive to unlock.


Controller: 7.5


I don't have a problem with playing it, but you can remap controllers easily, and it supports controllers. It would be an advanced custom controller option for expert players, and custom firing would be nice.


Environment: 3.5


Eh, I suppose that's alright, but the hazard area with the lightning trees and plants thingy is quite okay. I'm sure you can use a counter, like a Mobile Lightning Rod, to protect against lightning trees. I thought it was a cool concept to have stones and trees that can be destroyed easily, but it took hours to collect resources. I feel like I'm wasting my time, especially when there are occasional bugs that cause plant explosions that can kill you once or twice. It's just really annoying overall.


User Interface: 1.5


The user interface is causing me discomfort and confusion, and it also seems to have some bugs that need to be addressed. I believe it's just a visual issue that needs to be fixed, but it's definitely frustrating and requires attention.


Performance: 10


I thought my PC was all good since it's been running smoothly with no problems. But, I've noticed a little issue when trying to set the frame rate limit higher than 60. It won't go beyond that unless I set it to unlimited. Maybe this only happens when I play the game in windowed mode or there's some other small detail causing it. Anyway, it would be awesome if there was a way to tweak the settings and get around this limit. Aside from this small hiccup, everything else is working great, and I don't have any complaints.


[h1]Overall Current State General Rating - 8.7/10[/h1]

I know, early access and all. But this was released before it was ready for public view. There's just not enough here and what is here isn't fun.

That said, after careful thought, I will not be refunding. Payload Studios has earned the trust from the first Terratech, an amazing game that they have supported without significant paid DLC for nearly a decade, that they will eventually turn this into something great. The roadmap is promising, and while I have issues with design decisions as they stand, I think it's clear they have the message from the community and will work on them. I look forward to playing this 6 months or a year from now, and changing this review then. But for now, I can not in good conscience suggest someone buy the game in the state it's in.

Please Payload, don't betray that trust. I want to see what Terratech really should be. It's not there yet, but I expect it will be eventually.

My personal gripes:
The resource grind is awful.
The base building is slow, messy and unfun.
The UI is complicated, confusing and just frustrating to deal with.
The power system, both base and tech are frustrating and seem to do nothing but force fiddly micromanagement and slow down progress unnecessarily.

Things I will say I enjoy:
Driving around your tech feels good. Flat land, going over bumps, climbing hills. It all feels really good. I won't say it's perfect, but if it stays as it is I'll be happy.
The increased complexity of tech parts and weapons seems really interesting and I'm excited to build with them once I finally get there.
I'm looking forward to the multiple planets and potentially increased complexity of flying techs.

Once again, Payload, please keep working at it and while I'm sure this isn't the reception you wanted from your initial release, if you can get past this I have confidence you can make something that'll surpass the original in every way.

161435434.developer_response:
Hello, designer here.

Thanks for giving it a go and sharing your thoughts. As you know, we're always listening and we're keen to focus on updates that players want.

We've just pushed the balance update that addresses some of the issues that you mentioned. More info on it can be found here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

To your points specifically:

1. Resource grind has been reduced in multiple ways. Resource lasers consume less power and generate less heat now, and the health of many of the resource givers (ores, rocks trees etc.) has been reduced. The common uses for resources have also been reduced, for example - many of the ammo recipes have been made cheaper and craft faster. Once you build a fragmenter you'll also find that it yields more resources than before too. The cargo space for many of the cabs has been increased and the objective which teaches you how to build small cargo blocks (cargo expansions) has been updated to make it a clearer flow. All of that is in the current update. In the next update (likely coming next week), we're also taking further steps (like stack size increases for all resources).

2. Can you please tell me more about your issues with base building? We have plans to improve the structure block placement soon, being able to lock to just change the depth axis when trying to position a structure will be useful.

3. You're not alone in your UI frustrations, again, if you could please share some specifics it would help us knock issues out in the right order.

4. We've reduced micromanagement/upkeep for the power system - carbon generators now burn raw carbon for 1 minute (up from 20 seconds), and refined and pure carbon will burn for much longer still too.

Thanks for the positives in your review too and thanks for trying TTW out. I know you've said you'll take another look further down the line, but yeah, if you have time please check the update out and give us some more feedback.

161354495.review:
(Pre update launch review) I cannot in good faith, after having played the original, recommend this game to anyone. It is horribly grindy, resource stack sizes are just downright microscopic (30 units in one slot, awful.) which forces the player to spam storage units everywhere, which, by the way, take forever to craft.

What happened to Plumbite? Fibrewood??? You already HAD fantasy resources, why did you transition to boring real life space crap like Carbon and Niobium? Where are the missions? Factions??? Licenses for those factions- OH, oh, I see, you have to buy individual parts in the shop after grinding your balls into a fine paste and factions are all but gone, thats cool.

You know, you guys had a really, really good thing with the original, what exactly happened here?

Lets go down the list of what isn't in this game, shall we? So we get an idea of how ABYSMAL this game REALLY IS. Conveyor belts no longer exist, the cute, funny, fantasy ore names are gone, techs no longer drop from the sky on drop pods and instead poof into existence from thin air, shops don't exist, you don't have an SCU (Containment unit, inventory for your blocks), delivery cannons, pace makers. Planets aren't procedurally generated, missions aren't procedurally generated, Corporations don't exist (Which might I add, means you don't unlock licenses for them anymore) components are gone, pumpjacks are gone, anchors are gone, underground resource nodes are gone, and airplane parts don't seem to exist anymore.

DIRECT. DOWNGRADE.

EDIT: SO! I have played this game for a few more hours, having gotten into the intricacies of crafting and primitive automation (I say primitive because HOO BOY, THERE'S SOME ISSUES HERE, WHY do we only have corners and straight line "conduit" pieces??? WHY???), I've experimented with some of the weapons, played around with structures and found Points of interest (Apparently, points of interest are... "Fist cargo drums" around the map that... sometimes have loot and.... sometimes have structures, sometimes.). I don't understand why each of our Tech Yards have to have a separate storage capacity, when in the game's established lore we have black hole storage units that just suck everything up and hold onto our entire block library for us to play with at our leisure, I get why it was done for balance, but why does it have to be so much of a slog to carry stuff from one point to another? I have to drive for 30+ minutes to get around the planet with horribly restricted inventory space, which means I end up leaving blocks, parts, ore, materials and stuff just laying around everywhere because I can't carry all of it (It really does not help when some weapons and blocks take up four inventory slots), now this wouldn't be such a big deal if stuff maybe despawned after awhile or if we had the aforementioned and previously lore established black hole storage units, but we don't, so I end up having to devote another 40+ minutes to trash pickup, god forbid something gets stuck in a tree or in an area protected by 8 shotgun plants, because then I have to waste more time I could be using exploring, mining or trying to figure out how to not freeze to death in the arctic poopy zone shooting stupid health bloated stormtrooper plants.

Now onto the automation side of things, this one really peeves me because we had such a good thing established in terratech already that I don't see why it needed such a dramatic change, firstly, lets set an example in the original game: I drive up to my base, I park the rear or wherever my resource collectors are on my tech in front of a collector (Which usually also has wireless chargers for the batteries on my tech) or group of collectors wired to conveyor belts attached to my base structure, the collectors grab all the resources from the containers on my tech and begin moving them into delivery cannons, silos, to refineries, or to an already started project in one of my fabricators. The base has filters, so each silo only holds a specific type of resource, fuel goes to generators, refined stuff goes to the delivery cannons, etc. This is how it was in the original game, and it didn't take long to begin finding anchors and conveyor belts, there were even little missions where you get to go meet other techs that teach you stuff, you didn't even have to do these if you knew what you were doing, but you were rewarded with parts and blocks to use to improve your tech and base structure if you chose to do them!

In this game, you get NONE OF THIS, NONE, the conduits only pull from one specific slot in a crafting station and can't even be interconnected with things like junctions or what have you (Because they seemingly don't exist.) , so you end up having to devote an entire mega silo to a single object like the scrapper, which has four slots and 5 connector points, assuming you want to connect all of this, you need like 20 conduits to get all four of those fricken connection points all wired up to A SINGLE SILO! ONE SILO! ONE FRIGGIN SILO!! so you end up having to WEAVE a CONVOLUTED WEB of conduits and silos to get stuff where you want it to go assuming you can muster enough willpower to open every individual silo and adjust every individual object in your entire base, that is.

Edit 2: Don't play it, don't buy it, not worth it, not enough content, nothing is properly explained, resource yields are incredibly low, even now. Don't buy this crap game, spend your money on something better, like Helldivers.
161354495.developer_response:

You're clearly an OG fan of TT1, so thanks, I was the lead designer on that too. When we first launched TT1 into EA in 2014 it was pretty bare bones, it took us 10 years to get it to where it is now. I think it's fair to say not to buy the game just yet. B-wait why's the review positive then?
The game needs work, But this isn't some overpromise underdev scenario it's just early access. I bought the game in part because I wanted to leave this very review and give some feedback on what I think.
This will be coming from the perspective of a TerraTech 1 player.

So please don't think I'm having a go at you over at Payload, Love your stuff. But I am about to bitch about it a bit in no particular order.

I miss the physicality of the resources that was in the first game, where resources pretty much never get stored in some black box of an inventory, now items exist in a way that they do in most games and I feel the novelty there has been lost.

The menus, I dislike the angled menus and the cyan blue, Makes me think of ark survival evolved, I just want dark mode, dark grey background white text.

One of the most enjoyable things in the original for me was being able to effectively build a mobile base, and the later in the game you were- the less tied down to a central base you were. the sheer scale of what you could build was ridiculous in a good way, I feed like worlds may be trying a bit too hard to balance itself? Terratech was enjoyable in part because it was just a sandbox where you had a lot of freedom to build however you like.

The game is using upscaling at the moment, I don't know the exact details on what type or what settings, But I seriously do not like it, really bad artifacting where it's almost like screen burn in- I can understand if this is just around to make the Early access builds run well but it's just outright bad at the moment.

A bit of Mario in Unreal so to speak at the moment, I think the blocks that make up bases and techs need to have some imperfections added to their textures to ground them better in the environment.
Actually getting on to bases, I don't like that they're a different connection size- like, If you've played space engineers there's small and large grid, that's the case at the moment in Terratech Worlds, This was not the case in the first game and I think I preferred it the other way.

The automation aspects of the game fall flat, Since techs are by their nature limited in size there's no reason to mass produce parts, and there's no way to automatically gather a limited but abundant amount of resources like the Auto Miners in Terratech 1.

How buildings handle their input/output kinda sucks, Each output slot needs it's own output pipe, which for machines like the scrapper which end up outputting a lot of different resources ends up with spaghetti conduits.

Inventories within a tech don't need to be labelled and separated imo, my suggestion would be that cargo containers (if you keep them) should just expand a unified tech inventory, right now I end up with 3 pages of different inventories and all the shift clicking functions break.

There's something very wrong with the sound for me, I'm using 7.1 Surround W/ Dolby Atmos, But hearing the sound in game it sounds either Stereo or Mono and quite compressed? Not quite too sure what's wrong but it's certainly not good.
While talking about sound, I miss the bangin soundtrack from the first game, I really hope we get a new soundtrack that's just as good, but in the meantime I wouldn't be opposed to using the first game's soundtrack as a placeholder!

I had no idea how to use the Mobile Lightning Rod at first, Died to a lightning tree thinking it'd activate automatically.
Completely missed that there was a Tab where you spend the currency to unlock parts and was very confused.
I keep accidentally picking up buildings while in menus and it is frustrating.
Please add options and filters for what items your tech can currently pick up, my inventory keeps getting spammed with wheels and I don't want any more wheels PLEASE.

There's most definitely more that needs improving, I'll be checking in each update and updating this review each time.
I have no doubt this game will do well with some love from the community and developers.

161212044.developer_response:
Hello, lead designer here.

Thanks for checking out TTW and putting some hours in, thanks also for playing TT1, I was lead designer on that too.

We've completed a balance pass today and will be testing it tomorrow and releasing it soon after (all being well). It addresses some of the issues you mentioned specifically:

Resource lasers now consume less power when being used.
Reduced costs and time for ammo crafting

You can find more details about it here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4105666832538508033

Sounds like you've spent a lot of time playing TT1. One of the issues we noted was that when we gave you the GSO one block at the start of the game, we essentially gave you the best hull block possible (1x1x1 with 6 APs) it meant that from then on, you could usually ignore any other hull block (why bother with 2x1x1 or 2x2x1? just use more one blocks). Usually, power curves dictate that you get more powerful/useful items later in the game and start with weaker/more limited ones. That's what we're thinking this time around for the block set.

In addition to lots of other changes, the update above also includes expanded reactor limits for all cabs, making building a bit freer/easier.

You make a fair point about enemies having unlimited ammo/power. Someone else echoed your thoughts on another review. We'll prioritise getting firing pauses into their behaviours. We can't give them limited ammo or else they would run out and look silly sitting there not doing much.

On the resource transportation front, we have tractor beams and flatbeds for moving the physical resource fragments to a processing structure for more resource yield. The flatbeds are a little fiddly right now, we'll have improvements for them soon.

Thanks for giving it a look, I hope you'll check back again soon.

Cheers,
Kris

[b]Original Review: March 22, 2024[/b] 
Played a good bit (~8h iirc) during the Next Fest demo and been enjoying it in EA so far compared to its previous iteration, with a few things still being iffy. If you prefer the less combat-oriented parts of the original TerraTech and don't mind working around some strange blocks and reactor limitations (which are better than the demo was), there's a good chance you'll like TTW so far.

My primary issues at the moment stem from silicon quantity (rocks are the early way to do so, but take a long time to get anything meaningful) and *some* recipes feeling relatively expensive (silos in general for one.) Good start to the EA but it has some progress to work through.

161767970.review: When you treat it like an independent game in early access, its delightfully addictive and fun. I like the improvements since the demo, feels like less of a grind and back to exploring an alien planet.

161191909.review:
[h2]Post update things are looking much better[/h2]
[b]still some wonkyness around repairing but everything else is comprehensively better[/b]

[h3]Casual gameplay:[/h3]
Progression is still there but the painful tedium has been removed; more resources that are weaker and seem to spawn faster. Carbon lasts longer and enemies drop more parts. Also energy amounts or the drain rate from resource lasers seems to have been improved a bit as well.

Further the game also hasn't crashed for me since the last couple updates. This is a much better gameplay experience.

[h3]Combat:[/h3]
With the camera problems fixed combat is now fun again and farming enemy techs for parts is actually enjoyable.

Repairing is still a bit of a sore point with me though. I liked that more batteries gave more repairs in the demo. Batteries were costly and often came at the expense of armor and other parts so it balanced things out. Further if your batteries were killed you lost the repairs that battery could have given you, requiring a more careful building methodology. With [b]repairs no longer being a combat mechanic[/b] in any way (can't repair in combat at all let alone burn a repair early to save a weapon or battery), and it being entirely unrelated to your build [b]the game has become a bit more simple[/b]. Which is a sad development. 

[i]I feel that more depth and complexity without being confusing is the heart of Terratech in general. It's why I love how frames and wheels interact in Terratech Worlds as well as the buffs other parts have.[/i]  

The bugs around repairing and having your tech repaired with parts missing and dropped on the ground will probably be patched in the future but for now that's also annoying.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]
Not much to say beyond this is where the game should have been to start with. Massive props to the devs though for listening to the community and putting together this rebalance patch. As a player it was rough to watch the game go downhill all the while knowing it could be better having played the demo.

Games a bit pricey, if it's on sale make sure to grab it.

[h3]Quick Edit:[/h3]
[b]Late game is pretty rough... ranging from just lacklustre to outright broken.[/b] 
-Mid game cabs are better than late game. 
-Becomes about environmental survival elements instead of fighting the ever more sparse enemy techs that never get stronger, (except one area in the ice biome).
-The methods of surviving said elements are tedious and buggy.
-Dedicated servers crash more and run worse than normal coop.

I'm sure this will get fixed down the road but for now it's pretty terrible.

161288675.review:
[h3]I love the original TerraTech, but...[/h3]
TTW leans too much in to survival-craft.  I wanted more set-and-forget base building not chasing iron chunks with limited inventory space.  Even if it gets better down the line, the first 90 minutes made me feel irritated at how slow cutting a tree is, or how I constantly need more and more iron/copper/whatever-the-heck, how I constantly run out of inventory space, etc.

It's really hard to recommend this game at this price because you have to [b]REALLY[/b] like survival-craft, but then, there are better OWSC games out there, all TTW adds to that genre is vehicle building.

[h3]It feels like an OWSC game with Vehicle Building, when it should be a Vehicle Building game with light OWSC elements.[/h3]

Seriously, having to manage ammo seems so counter to me, since they also implemented a mechanic to limit vehicle complexity, like why both?  I've seen the argument that [b][i]"it's very easy to craft ammo anyways"[/i][/b], then why even add it? It takes space in your cargo, which btw, why add that when you have money to limit what and how many block you have?!?!

There are now multiple mechanics that aim to limit the same things, and the simple-but charming game design of the original feels forced out in an effort to make something that resembles one of countless thousands of Open-World-Survival-Slop games...

The move to Unreal 5 naturally adds some shader compilation stutters to the mix and honestly, also suffers from the "Unreal Look", I personally don't mind it, but I do have to admit, the original's charming style will be missed.

On the other hand, there are massive improvements over the original TT:
 [*] Better block placement, no more permuting through every mountpoint with every orientation.
 [*] Four weapon groups, don't have to fire every weapon at the same time all the time.
 [*] Manual aiming.
 [*] Terrain deformation and better base-building.
 [*] A more polished physics engine (some minor bugs atm, but I'm sure they will fix them).

[h3]IF and I mean IF they add everything on the roadmap, this will likely be the best game in the vehicle building genre, I am rooting for Payload Studios, I've bought 6 copies of the original to play with friends, I want to feel the same way for TerraTech Worlds![/h3]

161300185.developer_response:
Hey, lead designer here.

Thanks for the feedback and thanks for playing TT1 too, I was the lead designer on that as well.

We've completed a balance pass today and will be testing it tomorrow and releasing it soon after (all being well). It aims to address some of the issues that you've had a rough time with:

Reduced resource harvesting grind in multiple different ways.
Increased the building limitations for all cabs.

You can find more details about it here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4105666832538508033

I know you're not keen on the building limits and that's one of the main things this update will address. We've expanded the reactor capacity and efficiency points on all available cabs. Starting at 220 for early cabs and going up to 400 for later cabs (these totals are combined reactor limits and efficiency points). 

We will also be adding more progression-based methods for expanding reactor limits beyond cabs soon, (not this update but likely soon after). Aux reactors were in the demo, they are an attachable block that increases the reactor limit for your Tech. They are currently being reworked to occupy a restore rather than burning fuel as players we not keen on a constant burn or running out in the middle of a fight. Again, more are planned beyond those two as well.

We're not trying to stifle your Tech builds, just trying to make it more of a satisfying achievement to build something impressive through progression and to be able to offer real challenges to use your end game Techs against in the later stages of the game. More unlimited/creative ways to play will follow, further down the line too.

Anyway, I hope you check the update out and give some more feedback soon.

Thanks!
Kris

161824406.review:
TerraTech Worlds. I would say that, overall, I am enjoying the game so far. It feels like the original TerraTech but is different enough to feel like a game of its own rather than a simple re-skin. I would say that this game, at the current time of writing, is a slight letdown compared to the original, but with a bit of tweaking, it could be just as good, if not better. I know there are a lot of bad points I mention here, but they could easily be turned into good points with care and attention.

So, the bad points:

1. Several of the systems feel overly complicated and clunky. This is most evident during storage and moment of Materials. Even though there is some automation, most moving stuff between containers must be done by hand. There is some effort to link them with "pipes", but they often fail to fill fast enough to keep up with production/refinement speed and take materials almost at random from the silos, meaning you have to babysit them.

One of the greatest things I loved about the first game was the ability to auto-sort various materials vi filters. This particular function is absent this time around. Hopefully, it will be implemented soon. Also, limiting the mounting points on the storage silos is incredibly limiting and frustrating.

2. The power grid is both a blessing and a curse. It is annoying to have to manually select which buildings are powered or unpowered in a 3D first-person view. It is also painful to have it reset every time something goes wrong. If you run out of power, you must manually turn it back on once you have solved the problem.

3. Navigation could be better. There is no heads-up compass, the map, when brought up is more akin to a local scanner, and it is far too easy to get lost. The first game was similar in this regard, but this somehow feels even worse. The only easy glance indicator is a tiny disc above your main cab with indicators of any base/dropped crates. The small scanner is also tied to your cab block, which can be obscured if you try to place your cab in a defended position.

4. Vehicle building is another item that feels like a "Side grade" from the first game. The new game acts as if it is deathly allergic to the "basic block," Making any build fiddly and irritating. Awkward mounting points seem to be put there just to drive me crazy when building. This takes away so much of the freedom of design, and I feel it is a massive step backwards.

5. Many mechanics feel unbalanced and need to be refined. The "Scrapper" (it has another name, but that's what it is) feels pointless right now. From what I have seen, it doesn't actually give you any more materials than manual mining and requires more/higher-level tech and power to use. This will hopefully be sorted out soon.

6. There are no mines anymore. Unlike the first game, you cannot set up mining rigs, so all of your material gathering has to be done manually. There are also no base defences, so you are often interrupted from your already annoying base work to have to defend it.

7. The amphibious ability is just bad. For the actual speed you can move in deep water, floating techs may as well not be there.

Okay, that was a rant, but now, onto the good stuff:

1. I love the closer feel to a survival game they have taken. Ammo, though at first annoying, adds to this, meaning you need to balance the number of things you "rig" carries to survive/fight/mine while out in the world. No one rig will be perfect at doing everything, which encourages you to have several "rig ideas depending on what you plan to do in the world.

2. The other techs out there aren't the only problem. You will face environmental hazards and native critters that will not like you. I Love this change; it feels great.

3. When harvesting, finding the weak points on nodes is novel and feels rewarding when you get it right. The density of nodes felt sparse when I started, but a recent patch has fixed this. Good job!

4. Combat feels like good old TerraTech fighting, bits being blown off, needing to aim for other tech's weak spots to cripple them. I love it.

5. Self-healing is a fundamental power, and the number of "block repairs" powers is a nice touch. Both feel like a medical kit for a survival game. Feels good. Please keep.

6. The love/hate feeling of the base power grid is here again. The idea that power is linked through the floor is good; please keep that. Fix the other bothers with it, and this is a thumbs up all the way.

So as a final note. Like the general direction the game is going, but could be refined. Still early access so willing to overlooks a few things, keep up the good work.

Generally a good game! Not as bad as most of the other reviews say it is in my opinion. Worth it if its on sale.

Things I Dislike:

Dying can be a bit annoying and resource locations could be made more obvious, but other than that, its a fun game. The main problem is things that aren't obvious. I couldn't figure out you had to shoot the base of the angry plants to destroy them until later. I didn't know where to find phosphorus and spent hours looking for a rock when I was supposed to shoot plants. I didn't know niobium comes from tantalum rocks. I'm still unsure about how tungsten spawns as I only found a single small rock of it.

The mission reward system could also change. Every time I completed a mission I felt underwhelmed by it giving me 20-40 BB$. It felt like the reward from the mission wasn't the BB$ but it was the chance to get a better reward from the next mission.

Even with the tech reactor buff, armor could probably take up less power. I cant build a vehicle with decent weapons and also not be destroyed immediately because of lack of armor. Refining lots of resources can be a hassle as you have to keep shift clicking them in because it only has one input slot.

Things I Like:

The reactor buff after the demo makes building more fun. 

I like the scrapper a lot, it makes common resources so much less of a stress. 

The biome system is very unique and I actually enjoy how the biomes aren't so vastly different. 

Because of the lack of weapons at the start, when you see an enemy with a gun you don't have, its even more exiting to try and take it without damaging it. 

I like it that you can forcefully overload your reactor to survive the arctic and that it dosen't damage your ability to regen battery as badly as the demo.

The manual aiming system is much more fun to use than automatic.

The dynamic terrain deformation with tire tracks in snow and broken resources is really cool.

The "electrici-trees" are thankfully not covering every single inch of the blue tree biome anymore compared to the demo





Suggestions/Bugs:

Like I said earlier, things could be made more obvious where to find them or what they do.

I dont know if this is completely intended but when the reactor is in the "hot" range, rocket fuel gets consumed extremely fast when using a booster.

Mining lasers dont get a discount when put on a weapon mount, I'm also not sure if this is intended or not.

Niobium is way too uncommon when mining tantalum rocks.

Both lithium and phosphorus could drop more. Or make electrici-trees breakable again.

The swamp rust/poison/whatever should be more obvious on what it does and what it comes from. It also takes too long for it all to expire, even while in water.

161327188.review:
At this point, Do Not Buy.

The number of issues is staggering but I'll go over the big ones.

The primary issue is power generation and management. The devs have gone with a 'push' style of power generation rather than a "pull" style. Basically, your generators push out the same amount of power all the time, burning the same amount of fuel all the the time, and then if there are systems that need it, they'll take it. Most other games of this genre use a 'Pull' style of power management whereby the generators only produce what's required by the systems that are using it, and burn fuel accordingly. If a unit isn't actively operating on something, it should have either zero power requirement or at least a very reduced amount. All processing units pull their full power load even when not operating. Further, non-fuel based power systems only work if there is a fuel-based system on the grid and operational. Solar, Battery, and Wind power are not allowed to function on their own if the carbon-burning system is not also turned on and burning fuel.

There does not appear to be a way to 'clear' an area of mob spawns. You have to fight your way through the same mobs every time you want to venture out away from your base. They are endless hordes and essentially keep you trapped within a few km of your base.

Upgraded cockpit units do not give you more generator power to work with. They seem to have better 'efficiency' but that mechanic is not adequately explained in game in a way that will give you enough information to take advantage of it.

Minor quibble: Mineral mining debris produces carbon, not silicon. There are beaches, but you can't mine them for minerals, most of which would logically be silicon. 

I got this for my son and I to play over his spring break and I absolutely regret buying it, but we're past the return point for hours, so I'm stuck with it.

Edit 42 game play hours later: I still have issues with the power system being push, rather than pull. Devs have been responsive to a lot of other issues, however, and have, for now at least, extended fuel burn time as a band-aid. Drop rates have increased but I'm still wondering why there is such a difference between Tantalum and Niobium given that they're listed with the same rarity (common). Tantalum comes out at about 4 to 6 times the drop rate of niobium (12 vs 2 or 3)
