Short summary: this game is a lot of fun, works well for an Early Access game, and has a very bright future. 

Details: Please ignore any review that complains about bugs. It's an early access game and the bugs I've seen are totally normal and small. Also, please ignore any review that complains "this isn't Terratech". It's not supposed to be the first game. It's a new game. The overall gameplay and mechanics have been reworked and are intentionally made much deeper and richer. The game has more interactions to it and is clearly meant to be more advanced than the first game. I am looking forward to playing this game over the next few weeks. I am also looking forward to the additions that will undoubtedly come as the game matures. Definitely recommend this game.

Update: After playing the game for 40+ hours, and after at least 2 updates being released by the developer, I can say that the game is definitely headed in the right direction. I consider the original game to be a model of what early access should be, with constant updates and more content being added along the way, and I expect this game to follow the same way. As of now, there are 3 biomes, a number of missions, plenty of tech parts available to build your tech, and a variety of challenges (yes, including grinding). The game already has far more in it than the original when it was released. Looking forward to the upcoming updates.

163325230.review:
So is Terratech Worlds the same game as 2018 Terratech?

In short... No. 

Sometimes to move forward change is needed.

Terratech Worlds is the sequel to Terratech (2018) with a complete overhaul to the game.  One of the things they've done to make it more challenging is the introduction of the "Tech Reactor Points"  Basically each cab now puts out varying amounts of energy in the form of Reactor Points, and each part you attach to your cab deducts one or more points.  Some parts can deduct points as well. So you're no longer able to build lag inducing tech's that stretch out to the Horizon.

In this reviewers opinion..  This is a positive.  Why?

In the original game it was way too easy to breeze through the missions.  Every thing you killed could be instantly added to your tech.  Once you got to a point where hover-pads were available, you could build a giant floating platform of death.  Too high for the enemy techs to shoot at while you rained down hell from above.  Where is the fun in that?  Where is the challenge? 

While some reviewers are crying "It's micromangement hell" the developers have made some changes to make less micromanagement.  For example: Shield and Repair bubbles are gone.  After a battle your tech heals automatically. You no longer have to pepper your tech with shield and repair bubbles, or worry that you accidentally left one part of your tech naked to the elements.

This new game also focuses on base building and crafting.  2 things that were optional in the original Terratech. In the original, you could essentially build a base on wheels.  Like a city from the movie "Mortal Engines" your tech could just run over the landscape sucking up everything.  This is no longer the case as now base blocks are base blocks, and vehicle blocks are vehicle blocks.   You can't put one on the other which leaves a nice bit of separation of duties.    One thing I see other reviewers complaining about with this aspect is "Power Management" but honestly, just build another power plant or two and you're good.

Combat has ditched the "Spacebar Simulator" aspect.  You actually have to aim now, and different weapons feel like they have actual mass behind them. For example, you can flip over a tank with your shells to expose the cab, then chew up the cab with your lasers. It can be difficult sometimes because with ballistic weapons you need to lead shots, but that's part of the challenge.  You have to be a little more strategic in how you engage enemies because you are limited now. Hiding behind trees, boulders, or even leading enemies into traps with the Flora.  All of these changes to combat make it feel a little more like a combat simulator, and less like a shooter.

Graphically, it's a huge boost from the original.  Biomes are lush with Flora. Mountains actually feel like mountains.  There are changes in weather, something that was missing from the original, and Water.  People had begged for water for so long.  Everything has been revamped and dialed up to 11, although I think it would be neat if they added fauna in addition to the flora.

Crafting also got a huge revamp. Recipe's have been simplified.  (at least at the level I'm on now) Each recipe is only 4 elements.  Elements are either raw, refined, or pure.  Gone too are the lag inducing conveyor belts, replaced with sleek new pipes.  Some of the factory stuff from the original is there, and some of it is completely new.  One thing new in bases/craft are base additions that give you some resistance to the damaging effects of heat, acid, cold, etc.

Now the game is not without its faults.  I think base management could be improved a little.  For example, highlighting a base component and pressing E.  The way those windows open up takes up nearly the entire screen, and if I have to switch to another base module, it's kind of a pain.  Even just building a base can kind of be a pain just with the funny angles you look at stuff.  Maybe do something like the old NES master blaster, where I can jump out *just* to build and manage my base.

Overall though, I loved the original terratech, and I really like where this one is going.  Some people have been vocal about the changes, but to me those changes are what make it a good challenge. It's early access right now, I'd grab it while it's still cheap.

161329323.review:
Edit: Flipping my review to positive, we'll see how this shakes out. The developers have issued statements saying they've heard us loud and clear, and they'll try to adjust the tuning to make this game more enjoyable. Not entirely sure why things ended up more restrictive (efficiency cap, things cost more, enemy techs drop less) from the demo to early access, but this is a good start.

To be clear, this isn't a vote against resource limits. I think they're a fantastic idea and would love more meaningful building than the original TT, however with the tuning set the way they were at EA launch, they were very restrictive and got in the way of fun more often than not.

Original review below:

This game is simply put, boring and excessively grindy. It seems like the developers of this game are so afraid of how the building system from the original TerraTech turned out (where people slapped hundreds of guns on a tech) that anything that deviates from "4 wheels, 2-3 guns" is immediately smacked down in the name of "game design" and "balancing".
Even when people did figure out cool ways to use the existing blocks and reactor points system, a new efficiency cap mechanic was added, very much in a "bUt NoT LiKe tHaT" sort of way. This feels very much like the Henry Ford quote "Any color the customer wants, as long as it's black". The developers seem so afraid of how things ended up in the previous game that they're willing to sacrifice everything, including player fun, to ensure that it doesn't happen again.

I understand that this game is still in early access, but there just seem to be so many user hostile design choices that have nothing to do with polish. You get a single save for your world, iron man mode. This prevents save scumming, but also means that if there are any problems with the save/load system, there are no backups for your save. I'm now left with a 4 hour playtime save that crashes my game immediately upon load. That coupled with the amount of grinding in lieu of proper game design has left a really sour taste in my mouth and I don't think I'll be back. 

As it stands right now, this game is very much deserving of its less than 50% positive review score.
161329323.developer_response:
Hi, designer here.

Thanks for putting the hours in and for sharing your feedback.

We've completed a balance pass today and will be testing it tomorrow and releasing it soon after (all being well). It addresses some of your points of concern (grind (I'm assuming harvesting) and Tech reactor limits). You can find more details about it here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4105666832538508033

I know you're not keen on the building limits, so we've expanded them on the available cabs in the (coming balance pass. Starting at 220 for early cabs and going up to 400 for later cabs (these totals are combined reactor limits and efficiency points). 

We will be adding more progression-based methods for expanding reactor limits beyond cabs too soon, not this update but likely soon after. Aux reactors were in the demo, but are currently being reworked to occupy a restore rather than burning fuel as players we not keen on a constant burn or running out in the middle of a fight. Again, more are planned beyond those two as well.

We're not trying to stifle your Tech builds, just trying to make it more of a satisfying achievement to build something impressive through progression and to be able to offer real challenges to use your end game Techs against in the later stages of the game. More unlimited/creative ways to play will follow, further down the line too.

Anyway, thanks again for the input, please do let us know how you get on after the update.

Many thanks,
Kris

161356558.review:
This game has none of the soul of the original game, and I don't see how the game can match that game without a serious make-over.

I was worried about this when playing the demo, but held out waiting to see if the full game would open up in a better way after a few hours. It does not.

Graphically it looks great, but lacks the original's style.
The UI is just abysmal and clunky.

The original had a great system where all blocks could be attached to everything with some limitations regarding angles and attachment points. This let you build vehicles, emplacements and massive mobile bases all using the same system. For some god-awful reason they decided that bases are now built from a separate pool of parts making them cumbersome and killing the entire concept of a nomadic mobile base. The lack of a universal item storage also means it's a huge pain to move your base once you set one up. Generally speaking, the pool of parts 10 hours in is extremely poor. 

The charm of the original manufacturers is just gone. 

Managing the base is intentionally made cumbersome by the way the power system works with no way to toggle things in bulk or manage in a centrally managed way. Maybe this is something that unlocks later, but after 10 hours of fucking around with this system, I'm just fed up with it.

In the previous game, all items were a physics item. You could suck up both equipment and resources and carry them in a physical way. This game has none of that. Once dropped, resources become a number in your inventory. The only resources you carry physically are the chunks you carry to a fracturing base part, and that is a cumbersome method that takes forever to shuttle 1-2 items at a time.

The balance is just abysmal. You're constantly grinding for resources to craft even the most basic items. It takes minutes of waiting to craft a few hundred rounds of ammo, that you expend in 10 seconds of shooting. The sheer swarm of enemies that are constantly respawning, have infinite ammo compared to you, and always gang up on you means you are always just trying to find resources for ammo, than actually progressing and exploring the world.

I realize the game only just arrived in only access, but I'm having a hard time seeing how this game can be salvaged.

Balance wise, it would help if natural resources dropped like 5 times as much, and your inventory could store more along a similar scale. I would tone down the spawns and give the player tools to deal with the currently-invulnerable hazards.

Structurally, there are huge quality of life improvements that need to be made to bring it closer to the charm the original had. Bases should not be there own classification. The reactor system is too restrictive. These for me are deal-breakers.

Okay, let me start this by saying - To those saying this game isnt worth the 30 dollars on release, please keep in mind this game is at most, 2 days old. Let me give you My insight on this game, given my experience on the former title (300 hours on the first game.)

1. Game Mechanics: Honestly, there's definitely ups and downs, but i can maybe only list off 2 or 3 downsides at most, while my ups are vast. For example, the new storage system is a big step forward, especially for the resources. Gone are the days of the resource receivers and in comes the inventory. It honestly was such a pain with the old system, and i feel that this is a lot better. However, this is also where we can spot the first downside - space. Tech parts seem to make up a large portion of one's inventory, meaning that you need storage ASAP. Thankfully the game gives you a storage straight off the start, but I feel like this just isnt enough for how fast some people can acquire parts (myself included). Another positive is the new building system. In  my eyes, this feels like 2 steps up in one, because of 2 major things the game has implimented. The first is the dedicated blocks for the base building, which means that finally, tech pieces cant connect or use base blocks. This was the main reason i never touched bases in the original game, as it just felt like such a hassle to get all the blocks needed while taking into consideration the blocks on my own tech, but now, that's been solved. The other half of this is the placing themselves. The blocks now actually go to where you want it, unlike the last game which felt overly-snappy, and wouldnt move off the nodes it first went to.

2. Combat: As it stands now, I do honestly think that there can be improvements. As me and my friends co-op world unfolds, we often find ourselves completely swarmed by enemies, much more then the previous game had. I feel like spawnrates are just too high at the moment, but if someone knows a setting i happened to adjust or forgot to change, please feel free to write an equally long comment on this, and try to make me feel ashamed about myself for voicing an opinion (Look my humor isnt great.) Another big thing, that i have seen previously mentioned is the lack of damage a weapon does. Honestly in my experience, I call BS on this. My current tech has only 2 resource lasers and 2 machine guns, and i find this more then enough for most techs.. however, this leads to the other part of their complaints. Ammo. I am in full agreeance on this with the people critical of the game - something about crafting ammo in TTW just feels so.. foriegn. It just feels like an extra step in logistics, and in my opinion, something we could've gone without. But I do fully understand why this mechanic was created,likely because of how ridiculous techs of the original game were as far as firepower went, so this was likely their way of stopping that.

3. Literally anything else: Okay, this is probably gonna turn into a rant, so grab your popcorn. Firstly, Im gonna touch on all the things I think the game can add and help improve on. First thing to be improved: UI. Now, i dont find any issues with how it performs, the only thing i really just wannt see is the ability to customize the color, just to make it more to ones liking ( dont know how easy this would be.) Another thing - being able to change the color of base tiles that you place. Again, dont know if this is in the game or not, but it'd be nice to change the color from the standard orange.

id give this a solid 8/10 for launch, one of the best recent games thats come out on launch, I dont care what standards other people have.

161282776.review:
Review Disclaimer: This review follows the notion that Terratech Worlds is NOT Terratech. I view that both have the block tech mechanics from the first game, enemy techs, and resource gathering and crafting, but that's about where the core similarities end.

Terratech Worlds is an interesting game in its early access stage. I had connection issues at launch, though those worked themselves out, and the controls took a bit to get a hang of (For the first hour after the tutorial I felt like the reason why I couldn't move my controller cursor was a bug. It wasn't.)

First off, the subtle elephant in the room. This won't likely be noticeable unless you do multiple saves, or play singleplayer and multiplayer: The worlds aren't randomly generated, from what I can see, and what the community has told me. If this is how it'll be going forward, I'll be mostly disappointed, because part of the reason why I love Terratech so much is because of the replay value whenever a new content update drops.

Next, the reactor and axel/frame/weapon mount system and ammo/inventory systems. I actually like these balance changes compared to Terratech. A few glaring issues I had with Terratech was the amount of weapon/bullet spam a lot of mid-to-late-game enemy techs had, and is part of the reason why I decided to start playing around with Hawkeye blocks in that game before the release of this one, as their larger weapons are slow but powerful. Seeing an ammo/energy resource system in this game made me gleeful, as it means that trying gun spam here will only eat through your ammo/energy way faster, and will leave you vulnerable. But also seeing ways to make your wheels and weapons more efficient makes it feel more balanced. Overall, a positive change.

The resource gathering, at first, started to feel like a slog. The moment I found out about seams, that all changed. I love this mechanic. It adds variety, and makes gathering resources with ballistic weapons a bad idea against minerals without making resources painful to deal with.

The changes to how blocks fall off your tech and how repairing works is also a great improvement. There have been times where I forget to screenshot my tech and lose a LOT. Having it this way is makes recovery a lot easier and less punishing to your tech.

I like the conduit system, but just having straight and corner conduits to work with is a bit annoying without having any sorting or splitting to automate just slapping debris and carbon into a silo and having it all turned into refined carbon.

Setting up base anywhere besides your spawn area is awful. I tried setting up base near the biome with blue trees, and I could not get any of the missions done, as both me and my base were absolutely PELTED with enemies with higher-grade weapons (especially plasma weapons) that I just couldn't deal with. Combined with how high-up the camera is, and I just had to restart from scratch.

I had a severe framerate issue when I simply looked at the sky, even on the Steam Deck with all of the settings set to "Low", which was kind of obnoxious to deal with. The game could definitely use some optimization.

I like the licensing changes, however, I'm sad that acquiring licenses to a corporation's blocks was not a mechanic that was brought back.

Overall, I like the direction that the game has taken, and I look forward to see where the game goes from here. It's not without its flaws, but those are expected in early access. I give this game a rating of 7/10. I hope this review makes it to the devs and brightens their day amidst all the negative reviews.

161474334.developer_response:
Hello, designer here.

Wow, you've put some hours in already. Thanks for checking it out and thanks for the feedback.

We've just pushed the balance update that expands the reactor limits for all cabs to allow for more freedom in your Tech builds. More info on it can be found here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

In the update (that is live right now), we've expanded the reactor capacity and efficiency points of all cabs. the early game ones have been pushed up to a combined total of 220 to 250, the later cabs are now at a total of 360 to 400 across both reactor capacity and efficiency points. these new limits allow for much more freedom in Tech builds. Beyond this most recent update, we will be reintroducing the aux reactor blocks too soon. They're attachable Tech blocks that increase your reactor capacity. They were present in the demo but reliant on constant fuel burn, we're currently reworking them to occupy a restore (one of your three auto rebuild charges) instead. We also have plans for further progression-based expansions to enable even larger Tech builds beyond that too.

Progression/resource grind has been reduced in multiple ways. Resource lasers consume less power and generate less heat now so they can be fired for longer. The health of many of the resource givers (ores, rocks trees etc.) has been reduced. The common uses for resources have also been reduced too, carbon generators now burn raw carbon for 1 minute (up from 20 seconds) and many of the ammo recipes have been made cheaper and crafted faster. Once you build a fragmenter you'll also find that it yields more resources than before too. The cargo space for many of the cabs has been increased and the objective which teaches you how to build small cargo blocks (cargo expansions) has been updated to make it a clearer flow. All of that is in the current update. In the next update (likely coming next week), we're also taking further steps (like stack size increases for all resources).

We've not reduced the number of enemies in this update, but we have increased the number of blocks that they drop (back up to demo levels) and also increased the amount of ammo that they drop too, making it easier to stay in the fight. In the next update (coming next week) we have adjusted their combat behaviour to be less relentless (for example they won't fire continuously without any pauses anymore and their accuracy has been adjusted to make things more fair).

A world gen would be great, as you say. It's our ambition to get to that stage where we can re-roll whole planets or various aspects of them, but much of the world is handmade right now. Not ruling world gen out further down the line, but it will take us a bit to get there.

Anyway, thanks for playing. I hope you'll check the update out and share your thoughts on it once you've had a go.

Many thanks,
Kris

161534159.developer_response:
Hello, lead designer here.

Thanks for giving it a try and for playing TT1 too (I was the lead designer on that as well).

We've just released an update with bunch of balance improvements, more info here: https://store.steampowered.com/news/app/2313330/view/4168717862237664899?l=english

Resource grind has been reduced in multiple ways. Resource lasers consume less power and generate less heat now, and the health of many of the resource givers (ores, rocks trees etc.) has been reduced. The common uses for resources have also been reduced too, carbon generators now burn raw carbon for 1 minute (up from 20 seconds) and many of the ammo recipes have been made cheaper and crafted faster. Once you build a fragmenter you'll also find that it yields more resources than before too. The cargo space for many of the cabs has been increased and the objective which teaches you how to build small cargo blocks (cargo expansions) has been updated to make it a clearer flow. All of that is in the current update. In the next update (likely coming next week), we're also taking further steps (like stack size increases for all resources).

Fair comment on the specificity of the block shapes. Our thinking was based on the idea that giving the GSO one block (1x1x1 with 6 APs) at the start of the last game undermined interest in other hull blocks that came later (why use a 2x1x1 block when you can just use more of the old reliable one block?). Progression curves usually follow that you get weaker/more limited items early in the game and unlock better/more useful items later. But you're not alone in this feedback so we're considering options. Nothing concrete yet, but thanks for the feedback there.

That said, we have expanded the reactor capacity and efficiency points of all cabs making it easier to build larger Techs. The early game cabs have been pushed up to a combined total of 220 to 250, the later cabs are now at a total of 360 to 400 across both reactor capacity and efficiency points. These new limits allow for much more freedom in Tech builds. Beyond this most recent update, we will be reintroducing the aux reactor blocks too soon. They're attachable Tech blocks that increase your reactor capacity. They were present in the demo but were reliant on constant fuel burn, we're currently reworking them to occupy a restore (one of your three auto rebuild charges) instead. We also have plans for further progression-based expansions to enable even larger Tech builds beyond that too.

We're also working on lots of improvements to base automation, but more to say on that soon.

It's clear that you played a lot of the first game. I really hope you'll stay with us on our journey with TTW, we spent 10 years adding things to TT1 so it's hard to match it for content out of the gate, but TTW gives us the ability to do all sorts of things that were not possible to deliver in the original (untethered multiplayer, terrain deformation and water, to name a few things).

Anyway, thanks for playing and for the feedback, please let us know what you think once you've had a look at the update, we're always keen to hear how people are getting on.

Cheers,
Kris
